pullRequest.body:
Add criteria for zpowers of analytic functions to remain analytic. Show that "`f * g` analytic" implies "`g` analytic" away from zeros of `f`.

This material is used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Hi Stefan,

I see you have written all the lemmas twice: once for the "un-applied" form `f * g` etc, and once for the "fully applied" form `fun x => f x * g x`. I think the mathlib convention is to prefer `fun x => f x * g x` where possible rather than doing everything twice (compare `Continuous.mul`, `ContinuousAt.mul`, `DifferentiableAt.mul`), and to simp with `Pi.mul_def` or `Pi.mul_apply` if you have to pass from the `f * g` form to the `f x * g x` form.

Best regards, David

Dear David, @loefflerd,

I understand your comment about the duplicated theorems. I have, however, received conflicting information on the issue. I am therefore unsure how to proceed and would like to ask your advice.

Long story: Many tactics, including "rw" and "fun_prop" cannot tell that "f*g" and "fun x \maps f x * g x" are the same. To apply a tactic, I often needed to cast between two definitionally equivalent formulations, which became rather tedious. I asked several people about the best practise here and was consistently told (e.g. by lean core team member @nomeata and mathlib maintainer @TwoFX) that duplicating theorems is the way to go. So far, I tried to be extremely explicit about the duplications in the descriptions of my pull requests (such as [this one](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21057)), but stopped after #21057 passed review without any comment and was approved by @sgouezel.

How should we proceed? Continue one way or the other? Bring the issue up on Zulip? Personally, I prefer the duplications but I do not have a very strong opinion here. If you would like to insist that I remove the them, I can simply do that.

Best wishes ‑ Thank you for your time,

Stefan.

I’m certainly not insisting on anything (and I have no authority to insist even if I wanted to). I personally don’t mind at all if these lemmas go in as they are, and the fact that you have found them useful in your own project is a pretty strong atrgument in their favour. I was only trying to anticipate objections which might be raised later in the review process.

We could discuss this one on Zulip if you feel it’s important to obtain a community consensus, but I’m not convinced it’s worth it for a few (arguably) duplicated lemmas.

@loefflerd Dear David, thanks for your understanding. Like you, I would not open a discussion on Zulip, and prefer to leave things as they are.

Best wishes from the foggy Black Forest, Stefan.
I agree with not having the duplicate point-ful and point-free definitions: I think the Mathlib standard and the previous non-duplicated setup was better.

I have opened a discussion at https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Convention.20for.20.60f.20*.20g.60.20and.20.2F.20or.20.60fun.20x.20.E2.86.A6.20f.20x.20*.20g.20x.60/near/501264041
@sgouezel As you suggested, I switched to the naming convention agreed upon in your Zulip discussion.
@sgouezel I don't know who is in charge of this, but the continuous integration failed after a few seconds with 'Error: No space left on device'.

Finally the naming convention has been adopted, and it's not the one we started with (see the last paragraph of https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html). Could you adapt the PR to this new convention?
@sgouezel Will do. Thanks for all your work. I am honestly impressed by your professionalism and patience in handling this very long and rather convoluted discussion.
This looks good, thanks for the PR + also for getting the conventions clarified! I found a minor golf, and I also admit to a certain scepticism whether we need the `zpow_nonneg' lemmas at all.

```suggestion
  simpa [← zpow_natCast, hn] using hf.pow n.toNat
```
(identical code also works for the other three similar lemmas)
Implemented as suggested. Thanks!
This lemma doesn't exist for `Continuous`, `ContinuousAt`, `Differentiable`, etc (+ I don't think anyone's particularly missed them). Is there a specific reason why this is needed?

I understand your concerns. I use the lemma several times in Project VD, typically in computations involving orders of meromorphic functions, for instance when I compute the order of the sum of two meromorphic functions.

The most elementary application is perhaps the statement that a meromorphic function `f` in normal form is analytic if its order `n` is non-negative. Mermomorphic in normal form means that `f` looks like `(z-z₀)^(untop n)*g`, where `g` is analytic. The lemma now says that `(z-z₀)^(untop n)` is analytic, and we are done. I am sure there must be other ways to argue, e.g. by using non-negativity to cook up a natural number that typecasts to `untop n` and then use `pow`, but I found those solutions a bit workaroundish and somewhat clumsy.

How shall we proceed? If you want me to remove the lemma(s), let me know and I will do that.

"Using non-negativity to cook up a natural number that typecasts to untop n" sounds like the sort of thing that the `lift` tactic is good for. But if you find these `zpow_nonneg` lemmas handy then by all means keep them, it certainly doesn't do any harm to have them in mathlib.

pullRequest.title: feat: add elementary analyticity criteria
